electricityCost.title: Electricity calculator
electricityCost.description: Calculate the electricity consumption and cost of household appliances.

results.title: Results
results.noteText: Actual costs vary depending on rates and usage.

infographic.energyDescription: Consumption in kWh by power and time

meta.title: Electricity calculator - calculation of consumption and cost
meta.description: Calculate how much electricity household appliances consume. Online electricity cost calculator based on power and operating time.

overview.title: About the calculator
overview.content: Enter the power, operating hours per day, number of days and tariff per 1 kWh - get the consumption and cost for each device and in total.
overview.additionalContent: The electricity cost calculator allows you to calculate the consumption and cost of electricity for one or more household appliances at the same time. You can add an unlimited number of devices, each with its own power, operating time and tariff parameters. The calculator automatically sums up the total consumption and cost. The results can be exported to CSV for further analysis.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of electricity cost calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating the consumption and cost of electricity for various household appliances:

example1.title: Example 1: Electric kettle
example1.description: A 2000 W electric kettle works 0.5 hours a day for 30 days
example1.input: Power: 2000 W, Hours/day: 0.5 h, Days: 30, Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example1.calculation:
Consumption: (2000 W × 0.5 h × 30 days) / 1000 = 30 kWh
Cost: 30 kWh × 5.5 ₽/kWh = 165 ₽
example1.note: The electric kettle consumes a lot of energy in a short time, but does not last long

example2.title: Example 2: Refrigerator
example2.description: 150 W refrigerator runs 24 hours a day for 30 days
example2.input: Power: 150 W, Hours/day: 24 h, Days: 30, Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example2.calculation:
Consumption: (150 W × 24 h × 30 days) / 1000 = 108 kWh
Cost: 108 kWh × 5.5 ₽/kWh = 594 ₽
example2.note: The refrigerator runs constantly, but consumes less energy

example3.title: Example 3: Washing machine
example3.description: A 2000 W washing machine runs 1.5 hours a day for 30 days
example3.input: Power: 2000 W, Hours/day: 1.5 h, Days: 30, Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example3.calculation:
Consumption: (2000 W × 1.5 h × 30 days) / 1000 = 90 kWh
Cost: 90 kWh × 5.5 ₽/kWh = 495 ₽
example3.note: The washing machine uses a lot of energy but doesn't last long

example4.title: Example 4: TV
example4.description: 100 W LED TV works 6 hours a day for 30 days
example4.input: Power: 100 W, Hours/day: 6 h, Days: 30, Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example4.calculation:
Consumption: (100 W × 6 h × 30 days) / 1000 = 18 kWh
Cost: 18 kWh × 5.5 ₽/kWh = 99 ₽
example4.note: Modern LED TVs consume significantly less energy

example5.title: Example 5: Multiple instruments
example5.description: Calculation of total consumption for several devices
example5.input:
Kettle: 2000 W × 0.5 h × 30 days
Refrigerator: 150 W × 24 h × 30 days
Washing machine: 2000 W × 1.5 h × 30 days
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example5.calculation:
Kettle: 30 kWh × 5.5 ₽ = 165 ₽
Refrigerator: 108 kWh × 5.5 ₽ = 594 ₽
Washing machine: 90 kWh × 5.5 ₽ = 495 ₽
Total: 228 kWh, Cost: 1254 ₽
example5.note: The calculator automatically summarizes the consumption and cost of all appliances

example6.title: Example 6: Air conditioning in the summer season
example6.description: 1500 Watt air conditioner runs 8 hours a day for 90 days
example6.input: Power: 1500 W, Hours/day: 8 h, Days: 90, Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example6.calculation:
Consumption: (1500 W × 8 h × 90 days) / 1000 = 1080 kWh
Cost: 1080 kWh × 5.5 ₽/kWh = 5940 ₽
example6.note: Air conditioning is one of the most energy-consuming appliances in the hot season

calculation.title: How is it calculated
calculation.content:
Consumption (kWh) = Power (W) × Time (h) / 1000
Cost = Consumption × Tariff (per 1 kWh)

tips.title: Council
tips.tip1: For continuous instruments, use the middle clock.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the energy consumption of an appliance online?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of the device, use the formula: Consumption (kWh) = Power (W) × Operating time (h) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W kettle operating 0.5 hours per day: (2000 W × 0.5 h) / 1000 = 1 kWh per day. In the calculator, enter the power of the device, operating hours per day, number of days and tariff - get an automatic calculation of consumption and cost.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity according to the tariff?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity, multiply the consumption in kWh by the tariff per 1 kWh in your region. Formula: Cost = Consumption (kWh) × Tariff (₽/kWh). For example, with a consumption of 30 kWh and a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 30 × 5.5 = 165 ₽. The calculator automatically calculates the cost for each device and the total amount.

faqItems.q: How to calculate electricity consumption for a month?
faqItems.a: To calculate monthly electricity consumption, enter the power of the appliance in watts, hours of operation per day and set the number of days to 30. Formula: (Power × Hours/day × 30 days) / 1000 = Monthly consumption in kWh. For example, a 150 W refrigerator running 24 hours: (150 × 24 × 30) / 1000 = 108 kWh per month. The calculator automatically calculates consumption and cost for the selected period.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity for several appliances?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity for several devices, add each device to the calculator with its parameters (power, operating hours, days, tariff). The calculator automatically summarizes the consumption of all appliances in kWh and calculates the total cost. For example, a kettle (30 kWh) + refrigerator (108 kWh) + washing machine (90 kWh) = 228 kWh in total. At a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 228 × 5.5 = 1254 ₽.

faqItems.q: How to find out the electricity consumption by the power of the device?
faqItems.a: To determine the electricity consumption based on the power of the device, use the formula: Consumption (kWh) = Power (W) × Time (h) / 1000. The power of the device is usually indicated on the label or in the instructions. For example, a 2000 W electric kettle operating for 30 minutes (0.5 hours): (2000 × 0.5) / 1000 = 1 kWh. In the calculator, simply enter the power in watts and operating time - the calculation will be performed automatically.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of household appliances?
faqItems.a: To calculate the electricity consumption of household appliances, add each appliance to the calculator with its parameters: power (W), operating hours per day, number of days of use. The calculator will automatically calculate the consumption of each device in kWh and their cost. Typical values: refrigerator (150 W, 24 hours) ≈ 108 kWh/month, washing machine (2000 W, 1.5 hours) ≈ 90 kWh/month, TV (100 W, 6 hours) ≈ 18 kWh/month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity online for free?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity online for free, use our calculator. Enter the power of the device in watts, operating hours per day, number of days and tariff per 1 kWh. The calculator will instantly calculate the kWh consumption and cost for each appliance, as well as the totals. You can add an unlimited number of devices and export the results to CSV. The service is completely free and does not require registration.

faqItems.q: What electricity tariff should I use for calculation?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity, use the current tariff in your region. Tariffs vary by region and can be single-tariff (single tariff) or multi-tariff (different tariffs day and night). The average tariff in Russia is 4-6 ₽/kWh. The exact tariff can be found on the website of your energy supply company or on your electricity receipt. In the calculator you can specify an individual tariff for each device.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the energy consumption of a refrigerator?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of a refrigerator, keep in mind that it operates 24 hours a day, but with cycling (turning the compressor on/off). The average power of a refrigerator is 100-200 W. Formula: (Power × 24 hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 150 W refrigerator for 30 days: (150 × 24 × 30) / 1000 = 108 kWh. In the calculator, enter the power of the refrigerator (100-200 W), 24 hours a day and the number of days - get an accurate calculation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of a washing machine?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of a washing machine, take into account its power (usually 1500-3000 W) and the operating time of one wash cycle (usually 1-2 hours). Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Number of washes) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W washing machine running 1.5 hours 30 times a month: (2000 × 1.5 × 30) / 1000 = 90 kWh. In the calculator, enter the power of the washing machine, the operating hours of one wash and the number of days of use.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity per month?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity per month, enter into the calculator the power of each device, operating hours per day and set the number of days to 30. The calculator will automatically calculate the consumption of each device per month and their cost. Sum up the consumption of all appliances and multiply by the tariff. For example, with a total consumption of 200 kWh and a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 200 × 5.5 = 1100 ₽ per month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the energy consumption of an air conditioner?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of an air conditioner, take into account its power (usually 1000-3000 W depending on the model) and operating time. Air conditioners operate cyclically, turning on when the set temperature is reached. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 1500 W air conditioner running 8 hours a day for 90 days: (1500 × 8 × 90) / 1000 = 1080 kWh per season. In the calculator, enter the power and actual operating time.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of a TV?
faqItems.a: To calculate the electricity consumption of a TV, take into account its power (usually 50-200 W for LED TVs, 100-400 W for older models) and viewing time. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 100 W LED TV operating 6 hours a day for 30 days: (100 × 6 × 30) / 1000 = 18 kWh per month. Modern LED TVs consume significantly less energy than older models.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity using a two-tariff meter?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity using a two-tariff meter, you need to divide consumption into daytime and nighttime. The daytime tariff is usually higher (5-6 ₽/kWh), the night tariff is lower (2-3 ₽/kWh). You can create two devices in the calculator: one with a day rate and operating hours during the day, the other with a night rate and operating hours at night. For example, the device works 16 hours during the day and 8 hours at night - create two records with the corresponding tariffs.

faqItems.q: How to find out the power of a device for calculating electricity?
faqItems.a: The power of the device is usually indicated on the label, in the instructions or on the device case in watts (W) or kilowatts (kW). If stated in kW, multiply by 1000 to get watts. The power can also be found in the technical specifications on the manufacturer’s website. For some appliances (refrigerators, air conditioners), consider the average power, as they operate cyclically. In the calculator, enter the power in watts for an accurate calculation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate computer power consumption?
faqItems.a: To calculate your computer's power consumption, take into account the power of the power supply (usually 300-800 W) and operating time. Actual consumption depends on the load: simple tasks (watching movies) - 50-100 W, games - 200-400 W. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 200 W computer running 8 hours a day for 30 days: (200 × 8 × 30) / 1000 = 48 kWh per month. In the calculator, use the average power taking into account the operating mode.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the energy consumption of a dishwasher?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of a dishwasher, take into account its power (usually 1500-2500 W) and the time of one wash cycle (usually 1-2 hours). Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Number of cycles) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W dishwasher running 1.5 hours 30 times a month: (2000 × 1.5 × 30) / 1000 = 90 kWh. In the calculator, enter the power, the time of one cycle and the number of days of use.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity for the entire apartment?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity for the entire apartment, add into the calculator all the main appliances with their parameters: refrigerator, washing machine, TV, computer, lighting, air conditioning and others. The calculator automatically sums up the consumption of all appliances and calculates the total cost. Typical apartment consumption: 150-300 kWh per month. At a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 200 kWh × 5.5 = 1100 ₽ per month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of a microwave oven?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of a microwave oven, take into account its power (usually 800-1500 W) and operating time. The microwave operates in short bursts, usually 1-5 minutes. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 1000 W microwave oven operating 0.5 hours (30 minutes) per day for 30 days: (1000 × 0.5 × 30) / 1000 = 15 kWh per month. In the calculator, convert minutes to hours (1 hour = 60 minutes).

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of an iron?
faqItems.a: To calculate the electricity consumption of the iron, take into account its power (usually 1500-2500 W) and time of use. The iron is usually used for 15-30 minutes at a time, several times a week. Formula: (Power × Hours of operation × Days) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W iron operating 0.5 hours a day for 30 days: (2000 × 0.5 × 30) / 1000 = 30 kWh per month. In the calculator, enter the power of the iron and the actual time of use.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity for a heater?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of a heater's electricity, take into account its power (usually 1000-2500 W) and operating time. Heaters can operate continuously during the cold season. Formula: (Power × Operating Hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W heater running 8 hours a day for 90 days: (2000 × 8 × 90) / 1000 = 1440 kWh per season. At a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 1440 × 5.5 = 7920 ₽. Heaters are one of the most energy-consuming appliances.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the power consumption of a hair dryer?
faqItems.a: To calculate the power consumption of a hair dryer, take into account its power (usually 1200-2200 W) and time of use. The hair dryer is usually used for 10-20 minutes at a time. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 1800 W hair dryer operating 0.25 hours (15 minutes) per day for 30 days: (1800 × 0.25 × 30) / 1000 = 13.5 kWh per month. Despite the high power, the hair dryer only works for a short time, so the overall consumption is low.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of LED lamps?
faqItems.a: To calculate the electricity consumption of LED lamps, take into account their power (usually 5-15 W per lamp) and operating time. LED lamps consume significantly less energy than incandescent lamps. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Number of lamps × Days) / 1000. For example, 10 LED lamps of 10 W, operating 8 hours a day for 30 days: (10 × 8 × 10 × 30) / 1000 = 24 kWh per month. LED lamps are 8-10 times more economical than incandescent lamps.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity for a water heater?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity for a water heater, take into account its power (usually 1500-3000 W) and operating time. The water heater operates cyclically, turning on when the water cools. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W water heater operating 4 hours a day for 30 days: (2000 × 4 × 30) / 1000 = 240 kWh per month. At a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 240 × 5.5 = 1320 ₽. Use insulation to save energy.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the power consumption of a vacuum cleaner?
faqItems.a: To calculate the energy consumption of a vacuum cleaner, take into account its power (usually 1500-2500 W) and time of use. The vacuum cleaner is usually used for 20-60 minutes at a time, several times a week. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 2000 W vacuum cleaner running 0.5 hours a day for 30 days: (2000 × 0.5 × 30) / 1000 = 30 kWh per month. Despite the high power, the vacuum cleaner only works for a short time, so overall consumption is moderate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the power consumption of a laptop?
faqItems.a: To calculate the power consumption of a laptop, take into account its power (usually 30-90 W depending on the model and load) and operating time. Laptops consume significantly less energy than desktop computers. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 60 W laptop running 8 hours a day for 30 days: (60 × 8 × 30) / 1000 = 14.4 kWh per month. Laptops are 3-5 times more economical than desktop computers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity for an electric heated floor?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity for an electric heated floor, take into account its power (usually 150-200 W per m²) and operating time. Heated floors usually work 8-12 hours a day during the cold season. Formula: (Power × Area × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, underfloor heating 150 W/m² on an area of ​​10 m², operating 10 hours a day for 90 days: (150 × 10 × 10 × 90) / 1000 = 1350 kWh per season. At a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 1350 × 5.5 = 7425 ₽.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of a multicooker?
faqItems.a: To calculate the power consumption of a multicooker, take into account its power (usually 600-1200 W) and operating time. The multicooker operates cyclically, turning on to maintain temperature. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, an 800 W multicooker operating 2 hours a day for 30 days: (800 × 2 × 30) / 1000 = 48 kWh per month. A multicooker is more economical than an oven, as it retains heat better.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the electricity consumption of an oven?
faqItems.a: To calculate the electricity consumption of the oven, take into account its power (usually 2000-4000 W) and operating time. The oven is usually used for 1-2 hours at a time several times a week. Formula: (Power × Operating hours × Days) / 1000. For example, a 3000 W oven operating 1 hour per day for 30 days: (3000 × 1 × 30) / 1000 = 90 kWh per month. The oven uses a lot of energy but is not used often.

faqItems.q: How to export electricity calculation results to CSV?
faqItems.a: To export electricity calculation results to CSV, use the "Export CSV" button in the calculator. The results will be saved in a file with data about each device: name, power, operating hours, days, tariff, consumption and cost. The CSV file can be opened in Excel, Google Sheets or any other spreadsheet editor for further analysis or printing. Export is available for all added devices and totals.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of electricity at different tariffs during the day and at night?
faqItems.a: To calculate the cost of electricity at different tariffs during the day and at night, create two devices in the calculator: one with a day tariff and operating hours during the day, the other with a night tariff and operating hours at night. For example, the device operates 16 hours during the day with a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh and 8 hours at night with a tariff of 2.5 ₽/kWh. The calculator will automatically calculate the cost for each period and the total amount. A two-tariff meter allows you to save money when using appliances at night.

faqItems.q: How to calculate electricity consumption for a year?
faqItems.a: To calculate electricity consumption for the year, enter into the calculator the power of each device, hours of operation per day and set the number of days to 365. The calculator will automatically calculate the consumption of each device for the year and their cost. For seasonal appliances (air conditioner, heater), take into account their actual usage time. For example, with a total consumption of 2400 kWh per year and a tariff of 5.5 ₽/kWh: 2400 × 5.5 = 13200 ₽ per year.

faqItems.q: How to calculate energy consumption to save?
faqItems.a: To calculate energy consumption and optimize costs, use the calculator to analyze the consumption of all appliances. Identify the most energy-consuming appliances and consider replacing them with more energy-efficient models or optimizing usage time. For example, replacing incandescent lamps with LED lamps, using energy-saving modes for the refrigerator and air conditioner, disconnecting appliances from the network in standby mode. The calculator will help you compare different options and find the optimal solution.

faqItems.q: Is the electricity cost calculator free?
faqItems.a: Yes, the electricity cost calculator is completely free and does not require registration. You can use it an unlimited number of times to calculate electricity consumption and cost for any number of devices. The calculator works online, does not require installation of programs and is available 24/7. All functions, including multi-instrument calculation, automatic summation and CSV export, are provided free of charge. The service is financed by advertising and is an open tool for all users.

paper-weight.title: Paper weight calculator
paper-weight.description: Calculation of paper weight by density and number of sheets

seo.title: Online paper weight calculator - accurate calculation of sheet weight
seo.description: Free online calculator to calculate paper weight by weight, number of sheets and format. Supports all standard paper sizes.

overview.title: About the Paper Weight Calculator
overview.content: The online paper weight calculator is an accurate tool for determining paper weight by weight, number of sheets and size. Simply enter the paper weight, number of sheets and format, and get the exact weight in grams or kilograms.
overview.additionalContent: The paper weight calculator uses standard formulas to accurately calculate the weight of sheets of paper. The calculation is based on paper weight (gsm), sheet area and number of sheets. Formula: Weight = Sheet area (m²) × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets. The calculator supports all standard paper sizes: A4, A3, A5, Letter, Legal and others.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of calculating paper weight
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating paper weight for various formats and densities:

example1.title: Example 1: A4 office paper
example1.description: Office paper 80 g/m², A4 format, 100 sheets
example1.input: Density: 80 g/m², Format: A4 (210×297 mm), Number of sheets: 100
example1.calculation:
Area A4: (210 × 297) / 1,000,000 = 0.06237 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.06237 m² × 80 g/m² = 4.99 g
Total weight: 4.99g × 100 sheets = 499g
example1.result: Single sheet weight: 4.99 g, Total weight: 499 g (0.499 kg)
example1.note: Standard office paper for printers and copiers

example2.title: Example 2: Cardboard A3
example2.description: Cardboard density 200 g/m², A3 format, 50 sheets
example2.input: Density: 200 g/m², Format: A3 (297×420 mm), Number of sheets: 50
example2.calculation:
Area A3: (297 × 420) / 1,000,000 = 0.12474 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.12474 m² × 200 g/m² = 24.95 g
Total weight: 24.95 g × 50 sheets = 1247.5 g
example2.result: Single sheet weight: 24.95 g, Total weight: 1247.5 g (1.248 kg)
example2.note: Cardboard is used for packaging and creating durable products

example3.title: Example 3: A4 photo paper
example3.description: Photo paper 150 g/m², A4 format, 20 sheets
example3.input: Density: 150 g/m², Format: A4 (210×297 mm), Number of sheets: 20
example3.calculation:
Area A4: 0.06237 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.06237 m² × 150 g/m² = 9.36 g
Total weight: 9.36 g × 20 sheets = 187.2 g
example3.result: Single sheet weight: 9.36 g, Total weight: 187.2 g (0.187 kg)
example3.note: Photo paper has a higher density for high-quality photo printing

example4.title: Example 4: Letter paper
example4.description: Office paper 100 g/m², Letter size (216x279 mm), 500 sheets
example4.input: Density: 100 g/m², Format: Letter (216×279 mm), Number of sheets: 500
example4.calculation:
Letter Area: (216 × 279) / 1,000,000 = 0.060264 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.060264 m² × 100 g/m² = 6.03 g
Total weight: 6.03g × 500 sheets = 3015g
example4.result: Single sheet weight: 6.03 g, Total weight: 3015 g (3.015 kg)
example4.note: Letter format is common in the USA and Canada.

example5.title: Example 5: A5 Thin Paper
example5.description: Thin paper 60 g/m², A5 format, 200 sheets
example5.input: Density: 60 g/m², Format: A5 (148×210 mm), Number of sheets: 200
example5.calculation:
Area A5: (148 × 210) / 1,000,000 = 0.03108 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.03108 m² × 60 g/m² = 1.86 g
Total weight: 1.86g × 200 sheets = 372g
example5.result: Single sheet weight: 1.86 g, Total weight: 372 g (0.372 kg)
example5.note: Thin paper is used for books and notepads

example6.title: Example 6: A4 thick cardboard
example6.description: Very thick cardboard 300 g/m², A4 format, 10 sheets
example6.input: Density: 300 g/m², Format: A4 (210×297 mm), Number of sheets: 10
example6.calculation:
Area A4: 0.06237 m²
Weight of one sheet: 0.06237 m² × 300 g/m² = 18.71 g
Total weight: 18.71 g × 10 sheets = 187.1 g
example6.result: Single sheet weight: 18.71 g, Total weight: 187.1 g (0.187 kg)
example6.note: Very thick cardboard is used for business cards and postcards

methods.title: Calculation methods
methods.content: The calculator uses several methods to accurately calculate paper weight:

density.title: By density
density.description: Calculation based on paper weight in g/m²

area.title: By area
area.description: Calculation using sheet area and density

paperTypes.title: Paper types
paperTypes.content: Different types of paper have different weights:

applications.title: Application
applications.content: The paper weight calculator is used in various fields:

faqItems.q: How to calculate paper weight online by density?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper by density, use the formula: Weight = Sheet area (m²) × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets. Sheet area depends on the format: A4 = 0.06237 m², A3 = 0.12474 m², A5 = 0.03108 m². For example, for A4 (80 g/m², 100 sheets): 0.06237 × 80 × 100 = 499 g. In the calculator, simply enter the density, number of sheets and format - the calculation will be performed automatically.

faqItems.q: How to find out the weight of one sheet of A4 paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of one A4 sheet, multiply the area of ​​the sheet (0.06237 m²) by the density in g/m². For example, 80 g/m² paper: 0.06237 × 80 = 4.99 g. 100 g/m² paper: 0.06237 × 100 = 6.24 g. 120 g/m² paper: 0.06237 × 120 = 7.48 g. The calculator automatically calculates the weight of one sheet. and total weight for the specified number of sheets.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of a pack of A4 paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of a ream of A4 paper, use the formula: Ream weight = Area of ​​A4 sheet (0.06237 m²) × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets in a ream. A standard pack contains 500 sheets. For example, a pack of 80 g/m²: 0.06237 × 80 × 500 = 2494.8 g (≈2.5 kg). Pack of 100 g/m²: 0.06237 × 100 × 500 = 3118.5 g (≈3.12 kg). The calculator shows the exact weight for any number of sheets.

faqItems.q: How to determine paper density to calculate weight?
faqItems.a: Paper density is usually indicated on the packaging in g/m² or gsm (grams per square meter). Standard values: office paper - 80-100 g/m², photo paper - 150-250 g/m², cardboard - 200-300 g/m², thin paper - 60-70 g/m². If the density is not indicated, you can determine it by thickness: the thicker the paper, the higher the density. The calculator provides standard density values ​​from 60 to 300 g/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper by format and number of sheets?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper by format and number of sheets: 1) Determine the sheet area in m² (A4 = 0.06237 m², A3 = 0.12474 m², A5 = 0.03108 m², Letter = 0.060264 m²); 2) Find out the paper density in g/m²; 3) Use the formula: Weight = Area × Density × Number of sheets. The calculator automatically determines the area based on the selected format and calculates the weight.

faqItems.q: What is the weight of one sheet of A4 80gsm paper?
faqItems.a: One sheet of 80gsm A4 weighs 4.99 grams (approximately 5 grams). Calculation: area A4 = 0.06237 m², weight = 0.06237 × 80 = 4.99 g. This is standard office paper for printers and photocopiers. A pack of 500 sheets weighs approximately 2.5 kg.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of printing paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of printing paper, determine the number of sheets you plan to print, the paper size and its weight. For example, to print 1000 sheets of A4 100 g/m²: Weight = 0.06237 m² × 100 g/m² × 1000 = 6237 g (6.24 kg). The calculator will help you determine the exact weight of paper for your circulation and avoid errors when ordering.

faqItems.q: How to convert paper weight from grams to kilograms?
faqItems.a: To convert paper weight from grams to kilograms, divide the number of grams by 1000. For example, 2495 g = 2.495 kg, 5000 g = 5 kg. The calculator automatically displays weight in both grams and kilograms for convenience. Formula: Weight (kg) = Weight (g) / 1000.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of cardboard by density?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of cardboard, use the same formula as for paper: Weight = Sheet Area × Density × Number of Sheets. Cardboard has a higher density (usually 200-300 g/m²). For example, A4 sheet with a density of 250 g/m²: 0.06237 × 250 = 15.59 g. The calculator supports all standard cardboard densities and automatically calculates the weight.

faqItems.q: Which paper size is heavier: A4 or A3?
faqItems.a: At the same density, an A3 sheet weighs twice as much as an A4 sheet, since the area of ​​A3 is twice as large. Area A4 = 0.06237 m², area A3 = 0.12474 m². For example, at 80 g/m²: A4 weighs 4.99 g, A3 weighs 9.98 g. The calculator shows the weight for all formats and allows you to compare them.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of packaging paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of packaging paper, determine the total area of ​​the packaging material, its density and multiply. For example, cardboard with a density of 200 g/m² and an area of ​​0.5 m² is used for packaging: Weight = 0.5 × 200 = 100 g. If you need several sheets, multiply by the quantity. The calculator helps you accurately determine the weight of packaging materials for logistics and transportation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of book paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of book paper, consider the number of pages (each page = 1 sheet), book format and paper weight. Book paper usually has a weight of 60-80 g/m². For example, an A5 book (0.03108 m²) on 300 pages with a density of 70 g/m²: 0.03108 × 70 × 300 = 652.68 g. The calculator automatically calculates the weight of the entire book.

faqItems.q: How to determine the weight of paper without a calculator?
faqItems.a: To determine paper weight without a calculator, use the formula: Weight = Area (m²) × Weight (g/m²) × Number of sheets. Size area: A4 = 0.06237 m², A3 = 0.12474 m², A5 = 0.03108 m², Letter = 0.060264 m². Multiply the area by the density (usually indicated on the package) and the number of sheets. For accurate calculations, it is recommended to use an online calculator.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of photo paper for printing?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of photo paper, take into account its high density (usually 150-250 g/m²) and format. For example, 20 sheets of A4 with a density of 200 g/m²: 0.06237 × 200 × 20 = 249.48 g. Photo paper is heavier than regular office paper due to the special coating. The calculator supports all standard photo paper weights and automatically calculates the weight for any number of sheets.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of letter size paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of letter size paper, use a sheet area of ​​0.060264 m². Formula: Weight = 0.060264 m² × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets. For example, 500 sheets of 80 g/m²: 0.060264 × 80 × 500 = 2410.56 g (2.41 kg). The Letter format is common in the USA and Canada and has dimensions of 216x279 mm. The calculator automatically calculates the weight for Letter size.

faqItems.q: What is the weight of a ream of A4 paper?
faqItems.a: The weight of a pack of A4 paper depends on the density and number of sheets. A standard pack contains 500 sheets. At a density of 80 g/m²: 0.06237 × 80 × 500 = 2494.8 g (≈2.5 kg). At a density of 100 g/m²: 0.06237 × 100 × 500 = 3118.5 g (≈3.12 kg). At a density of 120 g/m²: 0.06237 × 120 × 500 = 3742.2 g (≈3.74 kg). The calculator shows the exact weight for any number of sheets and density.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for mailing?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper for mailing, determine the number of sheets, format and weight. Postal services take weight into account when determining shipping costs. For example, a letter with 10 sheets of A4 with a density of 80 g/m²: 0.06237 × 80 × 10 = 49.9 g. The calculator will help you accurately determine the weight of the correspondence and choose the optimal delivery rate.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper by area in square meters?
faqItems.a: If you know the total square footage of the paper and the weight, use the formula: Weight = Area (m²) × Density (g/m²). For example, 1 m² of 100 g/m² paper weighs 100 g. 5 m² of 80 g/m² paper weighs 400 g. The calculator automatically calculates the weight based on the sheet area and number of sheets.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of A5 paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of A5 paper, use a sheet area of ​​0.03108 m². Formula: Weight = 0.03108 m² × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets. For example, 100 sheets of A5 with a density of 80 g/m²: 0.03108 × 80 × 100 = 248.64 g. The A5 format is half the size of A4, so at the same density it weighs half as much. The calculator supports A5 format.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for design and printing?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper in design and printing, use a calculator, indicating the sheet format, density and circulation (number of sheets). For example, to print 1000 A4 business cards (cut into 10 business cards each) on 250 g/m² cardboard: 0.06237 × 250 × 100 = 1559.25 g. The calculator helps to accurately determine the weight of materials for ordering and calculating the cost of printing.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper by thickness?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper by thickness, keep in mind that thickness is indirectly related to density: the thicker the paper, the higher the density usually is. However, for an accurate calculation, it is the density in g/m² that is needed, not the thickness. Density can be determined experimentally by weighing a sheet of known area. Or use standard values: thin paper 60-70 g/m², standard 80-100 g/m², thick paper 120-150 g/m², cardboard 200-300 g/m².

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of A3 paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of A3 paper, use a sheet area of ​​0.12474 m². Formula: Weight = 0.12474 m² × Density (g/m²) × Number of sheets. For example, 50 sheets of A3 100 g/m²: 0.12474 × 100 × 50 = 623.7 g. A3 is twice the size of A4, so weighs twice as much for the same weight. The calculator automatically calculates the weight for A3.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for archival storage?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of archival paper, consider the number of documents, the format and density of archival paper (usually 80-100 g/m², sometimes special archival paper with a density of 120 g/m² for durability). For example, an archive of 5000 A4 sheets with a density of 100 g/m²: 0.06237 × 100 × 5000 = 31185 g (31.19 kg). The calculator will help determine the weight of the archive for planning storage and transportation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of self-adhesive paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of self-adhesive paper, keep in mind that it usually has a higher density (120-180 g/m²) due to the adhesive layer. For example, 100 sheets of A4 self-adhesive paper with a density of 150 g/m²: 0.06237 × 150 × 100 = 935.55 g. The adhesive layer adds 10-20% to the weight. The calculator calculates the weight of the base of self-adhesive paper; adjustments may be required for the exact weight with glue.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of printing paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of printing paper, determine the number of pages (sheets), book format and book paper weight (usually 60-80 g/m² for inside pages, 100-150 g/m² for cover). For example, an A5 book on 400 pages with a density of 70 g/m²: 0.03108 × 70 × 400 = 870.24 g. The calculator helps to calculate the weight of a book for planning circulation and transportation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of colored paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of colored paper, use the same formula as for white paper: Weight = Area × Weight × Number of Sheets. The density of colored paper is usually the same as white paper (80-100 g/m²). Color pigments add minimal weight. For example, 100 sheets of A4 colored paper with a density of 90 g/m²: 0.06237 × 90 × 100 = 561.33 g. The calculator works the same for all types of paper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of notebook paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of notebook paper, determine the number of sheets, format and density. Notepads usually use paper with a density of 60-100 g/m². For example, an A5 notebook with 80 sheets of 80 g/m²: 0.03108 × 80 × 80 = 198.91 g. If the notebook has a hard cover, add its weight separately. The calculator calculates the weight of notepad paper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for cards and postcards?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper for cards and postcards, use thick cardboard (200-300 g/m²). For example, 100 A4 postcards (cut into 4 postcards) 250 g/m²: 0.06237 × 250 × 100 = 1559.25 g. After cutting into 4 parts, each postcard will weigh approximately 3.9 g. The calculator helps determine the weight of the material for the production of cards and postcards.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of sticker paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper for stickers, please note that stickers are usually printed on self-adhesive paper with a density of 120-180 g/m². For example, 500 sheets of A4 self-adhesive paper with a density of 150 g/m²: 0.06237 × 150 × 500 = 4677.75 g (4.68 kg). After cutting into individual stickers, each sticker will weigh less. The calculator calculates the weight of the material for the production of stickers.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for envelopes?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper for envelopes, use a weight of 80-120 g/m² depending on the type of envelope. Envelopes are usually made from a single sheet of paper. For example, a C4 format envelope (229 × 324 mm, area 0.074196 m²) with a density of 100 g/m²: 0.074196 × 100 = 7.42 g. For 100 envelopes: 7.42 × 100 = 742 g. The calculator will help you calculate the weight of the material for envelopes.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of newspaper paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of newspaper paper, use very thin newsprint with a density of 45-60 g/m². For example, an A2 newspaper (420 × 594 mm, area 0.24948 m²) on 24 pages with a density of 50 g/m²: 0.24948 × 50 × 24 = 299.38 g. Newsprint paper is lighter than office paper due to its lower density. The calculator supports all standard densities, including newspaper.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of magazine paper?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of magazine paper, consider the weight of coated paper (usually 90-150 g/m² for inside pages, 200-300 g/m² for cover). For example, an A4 magazine on 100 pages with a density of 120 g/m²: 0.06237 × 120 × 100 = 748.44 g. An A4 cover with a density of 250 g/m²: 0.06237 × 250 = 15.59 g. The calculator helps to calculate the weight of a magazine for printing and transportation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the weight of paper for packaging materials?
faqItems.a: To calculate the weight of paper for packaging materials, use thick cardboard (200-300 g/m²) or corrugated cardboard. Determine the total area of ​​the package and multiply by the density. For example, a package with an area of ​​2 m² made of cardboard with a density of 250 g/m²: 2 × 250 = 500 g. The calculator helps determine the weight of packaging materials for logistics and delivery cost calculations.

faqItems.q: Is the paper weight calculator free?
faqItems.a: Yes, the paper weight calculator is completely free and does not require registration. You can use it an unlimited number of times to calculate the weight of paper of any size and density. The calculator works online, does not require installation of programs and is available 24/7. All functions, including calculations for various formats and densities, are provided free of charge. The service is financed by advertising and is an open tool for all users.

overview.title: About the water consumption calculator
overview.content: An online water consumption calculator will help you calculate how much water is consumed in a house, apartment, office or construction site. Suitable for cost estimation, plumbing design, pump selection and resource conservation planning.
overview.additionalContent: The water usage calculator uses standard water usage rates for different usage scenarios. The calculation is based on the number of residents/employees, type of premises and takes into account losses and leaks. Formula: Daily consumption = Number of people × Consumption rate (l/person/day) × (1 + Losses%). Monthly consumption = Daily consumption × 30 days. Annual consumption = Daily consumption × 365 days. The calculator automatically calculates the cost of water based on hot and cold water tariffs.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of water consumption calculations
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating water consumption for various use scenarios:

example1.title: Example 1: Apartment for 3 people
example1.description: Calculation of water consumption for an apartment with 3 residents, norm 200 l/person/day
example1.input: Scenario: Apartment, Number of residents: 3, Norm: 200 l/person/day, Losses: 5%
example1.calculation:
Daily consumption per person: 200 l
Daily consumption for 3 people: 200 × 3 = 600 l
Taking into account losses (5%): 600 × 1.05 = 630 l
Hot water (40%): 630 × 0.4 = 252 l
Cold water (60%): 630 × 0.6 = 378 l
Monthly consumption: 630 × 30 = 18,900 l = 18.9 m³
example1.result: Daily consumption: 630 l, Monthly consumption: 18.9 m³, Annual consumption: 229.95 m³
example1.note: Standard norm for residential apartments in multi-storey buildings

example2.title: Example 2: Private house for 5 people
example2.description: Calculation of water consumption for a private house with 5 residents, norm 250 l/person/day
example2.input: Scenario: Residential building, Number of residents: 5, Norm: 250 l/person/day, Losses: 10%
example2.calculation:
Daily consumption per person: 250 l
Daily consumption for 5 people: 250 × 5 = 1,250 l
Taking into account losses (10%): 1,250 × 1.1 = 1,375 l
Hot water (40%): 1.375 × 0.4 = 550 l
Cold water (60%): 1.375 × 0.6 = 825 l
Monthly consumption: 1,375 × 30 = 41,250 l = 41.25 m³
example2.result: Daily consumption: 1.375 l, Monthly consumption: 41.25 m³, Annual consumption: 501.875 m³
example2.note: In private homes, consumption is higher due to watering, baths and other needs

example3.title: Example 3: Office for 20 employees
example3.description: Calculation of water consumption for an office with 20 employees, norm 80 l/person/day
example3.input: Scenario: Office, Number of employees: 20, Norm: 80 l/person/day, Losses: 3%
example3.calculation:
Daily consumption per person: 80 l
Daily consumption for 20 people: 80 × 20 = 1,600 l
Taking into account losses (3%): 1,600 × 1.03 = 1,648 l
Hot water (30%): 1,648 × 0.3 = 494.4 l
Cold water (70%): 1,648 × 0.7 = 1,153.6 l
Monthly consumption: 1,648 × 30 = 49,440 l = 49.44 m³
example3.result: Daily consumption: 1,648 l, Monthly consumption: 49.44 m³, Annual consumption: 601.52 m³
example3.note: In offices, water consumption is lower due to the lack of washing and cooking

example4.title: Example 4: Construction site
example4.description: Calculation of water consumption for a construction site, norm 700 l/day per site
example4.input: Scenario: Construction, Norm: 700 l/day per site, Losses: 15%
example4.calculation:
Daily consumption per facility: 700 l
Taking into account losses (15%): 700 × 1.15 = 805 l
Hot water (30%): 805 × 0.3 = 241.5 l
Cold water (70%): 805 × 0.7 = 563.5 l
Monthly consumption: 805 × 30 = 24,150 l = 24.15 m³
Cost at a tariff of 50 ₽/m³: 24.15 × 50 = 1,207.5 ₽
example4.result: Daily consumption: 805 l, Monthly consumption: 24.15 m³, Cost: 1,207.5 ₽/month
example4.note: At a construction site, consumption includes concrete, watering, washing tools

example5.title: Example 5: Commercial premises (cafe)
example5.description: Calculation of water consumption for a cafe, norm 150 l/person/day
example5.input: Scenario: Commercial premises, Number of visitors: 50 people/day, Norm: 150 l/person/day, Losses: 8%
example5.calculation:
Daily consumption per person: 150 l
Daily consumption for 50 people: 150 × 50 = 7,500 l
Taking into account losses (8%): 7,500 × 1.08 = 8,100 l
Hot water (50%): 8,100 × 0.5 = 4,050 l
Cold water (50%): 8,100 × 0.5 = 4,050 l
Monthly consumption: 8,100 × 30 = 243,000 l = 243 m³
example5.result: Daily consumption: 8,100 l, Monthly consumption: 243 m³, Annual consumption: 2,956.5 m³
example5.note: In cafes and restaurants, consumption is higher due to cooking and washing dishes

example6.title: Example 6: Saving water with water-saving appliances
example6.description: Calculation of savings when installing water-saving devices
example6.input: Initial consumption: 630 l/day (apartment for 3 people), Savings: 30%
example6.calculation:
Initial daily consumption: 630 l
Savings (30%): 630 × 0.3 = 189 l
New daily consumption: 630 - 189 = 441 l
Savings per month: 189 × 30 = 5,670 l = 5.67 m³
With a tariff of 50 ₽/m³ savings: 5.67 × 50 = 283.5 ₽/month
Savings per year: 283.5 × 12 = 3,402 ₽
example6.note: Water-saving appliances can significantly reduce consumption and costs

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption in an apartment?
faqItems.a: Enter the number of residents and the appliances used - the calculator will show the total consumption.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to calculate water consumption for construction?
faqItems.a: Yes, the calculator takes into account construction scenarios (concrete, watering, washing tools).

faqItems.q: In what units is the result displayed?
faqItems.a: In liters and cubic meters, with the possibility of conversion.

faqItems.q: Can I add my own parameters?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can specify non-standard devices and consumption standards.

faqItems.q: How to find out monthly water consumption?
faqItems.a: The calculated daily volume is multiplied by the number of days of the month.

faqItems.q: Can leaks and losses be taken into account?
faqItems.a: Yes, the calculator adds the loss percentage of your choice.

faqItems.q: Can I use the calculator for an office or cafe?
faqItems.a: Yes, there is a calculation mode for commercial premises.

faqItems.q: Does the calculator take into account hot and cold water separately?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can set the proportion of hot and cold water.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to compare several scenarios?
faqItems.a: Yes, the results are saved for comparison.

faqItems.q: Is the calculator suitable for plumbing design?
faqItems.a: Yes, it helps determine the required flow rate for selecting pumps and pipes.

faqItems.q: Is it possible to download the calculation results?
faqItems.a: Yes, you can download the report in PDF or CSV.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the rate of water consumption per person per day?
faqItems.a: The water consumption rate depends on the type of premises: apartment - 200 l/person/day, private house - 250 l/person/day, office - 80 l/person/day, construction - 500-1000 l/day per site. The calculator automatically uses standard rates depending on the selected scenario.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for an apartment building?
faqItems.a: To calculate the water consumption of an apartment building, multiply the consumption rate per person (200 l/day) by the number of residents in all apartments. For example, a house with 100 apartments for 3 people: 200 × 3 × 100 = 60,000 l/day = 60 m³/day. The calculator helps calculate consumption for individual apartments and summarize the results.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption using a meter?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption on the meter, record the readings at the beginning and end of the period. The difference will show consumption. For example, the beginning of the month: 100 m³, the end of the month: 118 m³. Consumption: 118 - 100 = 18 m³ per month. The calculator helps you check whether the actual consumption meets the standards.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the cost of hot and cold water separately?
faqItems.a: The calculator automatically calculates separately hot and cold water based on established tariffs. Typically, hot water makes up 30-40% of the total consumption, cold water - 60-70%. Enter your hot and cold water rates and the calculator will show the cost of each category and the total amount.

faqItems.q: How to convert liters to cubic meters to calculate water?
faqItems.a: To convert liters to cubic meters, divide the number of liters by 1000. For example, 25,000 l = 25 m³. The calculator automatically shows consumption in both liters and cubic meters. Formula: Volume (m³) = Volume (l) / 1000.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the daily water consumption for a family?
faqItems.a: To calculate the daily water consumption for a family, multiply the consumption rate per person (200-250 l/day) by the number of family members. For example, a family of 4 people: 200 × 4 = 800 l/day. Taking into account losses (5-10%): 800 × 1.05 = 840 l/day. The calculator automatically calculates daily, monthly and annual consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a bath or sauna?
faqItems.a: To calculate the water consumption for a bath, consider: washing one person - 50-100 l, filling a pool - 500-2000 l, steaming - 200-500 l. For a family of 4, once a week: (100 + 1000 + 300) = 1,400 l × 4 times a month = 5,600 l/month. The calculator helps you include additional costs into your overall calculation.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for watering a garden?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for irrigation, use a rate of 5-10 liters per m², depending on the type of plant. For example, a garden of 100 m²: 100 × 7 l/m² = 700 l per watering. When watering 2 times a week: 700 × 2 × 4 = 5,600 l/month. The calculator allows you to add irrigation costs to your total consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water supply for a manufacturing enterprise?
faqItems.a: To calculate the water supply of an enterprise, take into account technological needs (production), household and drinking needs (employees), and fire-fighting water supply. The norms for office employees are 80-100 l/person/day. For production processes, use specific standards. The calculator helps calculate basic consumption for water supply planning.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a swimming pool?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a pool, consider: initial filling (pool volume), evaporation replenishment (2-5% of volume per week), filter washing (300-500 liters once a week). For example, a 20 m³ pool: filling 20,000 l, refill 20,000 × 0.03 × 4 = 2,400 l/month, rinsing 500 × 4 = 2,000 l/month. Total: 24,400 l/month.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a washing machine?
faqItems.a: Water consumption for a washing machine depends on the energy efficiency class: class A+++ - 40-50 liters per cycle, class A - 50-60 liters. With 3 washes per week: 50 × 3 × 4 = 600 l/month. For a family of 4 people with 2 washes per week: 50 × 2 × 4 = 400 l/month. The calculator takes into account washing costs in total consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a dishwasher?
faqItems.a: Water consumption for a dishwasher: class A+++ - 6-8 liters per cycle, class A - 10-12 liters. With daily use: 8 × 30 = 240 l/month. For comparison: manual dishwashing requires 20-40 liters at a time. The dishwasher saves up to 75% water. The calculator helps estimate savings when using equipment.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for shower and bath?
faqItems.a: Shower water consumption: 30-50 liters in 5 minutes (regular nozzle), 15-25 liters in 5 minutes (economical nozzle). Bath water consumption: 150-200 liters per bath. With a daily shower: 40 × 30 = 1,200 l/month. With a bath once a week: 175 × 4 = 700 l/month. The calculator takes into account the cost of hygiene needs in total consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a toilet?
faqItems.a: Water consumption for the toilet depends on the type of tank: old tank - 9-12 liters per flush, new dual-mode - 3-6 liters per flush (small mode), 6-9 liters per flush (full mode). With average use 5 times a day: old tank 10 × 5 × 30 = 1,500 l/month, new tank 5 × 5 × 30 = 750 l/month. Save up to 50%. The calculator takes into account toilet consumption in total consumption.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a heating system?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a heating system, consider: initial filling of the system (system volume), make-up for losses (1-3% of volume per month). For example, heating system 200 l: filling 200 l, make-up 200 × 0.02 × 12 = 48 l/year. The calculator helps calculate water consumption for various life support systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a car wash?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a car wash: car wash - 50-100 l, truck wash - 150-300 l, bus wash - 200-400 l. When washing 2 times a month: passenger car 75 × 2 = 150 l/month. Car wash with 100 cars per day: 75 × 100 × 30 = 225,000 l/month = 225 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate consumption for commercial properties.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a fire extinguishing system?
faqItems.a: To calculate the water consumption for the fire extinguishing system, use the following standards: internal fire water supply - 2.5 l/s per jet, external fire extinguishing - 5-40 l/s depending on the category of the building. The calculation is made in case of fire, and not for daily consumption. The calculator helps to calculate the main costs; for fire extinguishing, contact specialists.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a well or well?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a well or well, determine the flow rate of the source (l/hour or m³/hour) and planned consumption. For example, well flow rate is 1.5 m³/hour = 36 m³/day. When a family of 4 people consumes × 250 l/day = 1 m³/day, the well will provide consumption with a reserve. The calculator helps determine the required flow rate of the water supply source.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water flow for a pumping station?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a pumping station, determine the maximum consumption per unit of time. For example, a house for 5 people: 5 × 250 l/day = 1,250 l/day = 1.25 m³/day. Maximum hourly flow: 1.25 / 24 × 2 (unevenness coefficient) = 0.1 m³/hour. Select a pump with a capacity of at least 0.1 m³/hour. The calculator helps determine the required pump performance.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water savings from installing meters?
faqItems.a: When installing water meters, savings amount to 20-40% of previous consumption. For example, to the meter the fee is according to the following standards: 200 l/person/day × 3 people × 30 days × 50 ₽/m³ = 900 ₽/month. After installing the meters, the actual consumption is: 150 l/person/day × 3 people × 30 days × 50 ₽/m³ = 675 ₽/month. Savings: 225 ₽/month. The calculator helps estimate savings from installing meters.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water flow for a reverse osmosis system?
faqItems.a: The reverse osmosis system consumes water for cleaning and flushing: for 1 liter of clean water, 3-5 liters of source water are required. For example, consumption of 10 liters of pure water per day: 10 × 4 = 40 liters of raw water/day. Per month: 40 × 30 = 1,200 l = 1.2 m³/month. The calculator takes into account the additional costs of water treatment systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water flow for an irrigation system?
faqItems.a: To calculate the water consumption for the irrigation system, use the irrigation rate: vegetables - 5-7 l/m², lawn - 5-10 l/m², trees - 20-50 l per tree. For example, a 200 m² lawn with watering 2 times a week: 200 × 7 × 2 × 4 = 11,200 l/month = 11.2 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate flow rates for various irrigation systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a hotel or hotel?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a hotel, use a rate of 200-300 liters per room per day. For example, a hotel with 50 rooms: 250 × 50 = 12,500 l/day = 12.5 m³/day. Per month: 12.5 × 30 = 375 m³/month. At 70% load: 375 × 0.7 = 262.5 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate expenses for hotel properties.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a sauna or bath?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a sauna, consider: washing - 50-100 liters per person, steam room - 200-500 liters per session, swimming pool - 500-2000 liters. For a group of 10 people once a week: (100 × 10 + 300 + 1000) = 2,300 l per session × 4 times a month = 9,200 l/month = 9.2 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate the flow rate for recreational facilities.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water flow for an air conditioning system?
faqItems.a: Air conditioning systems with evaporative cooling consume water: central systems - 1-2 l/hour per 1 kW of power, window air conditioners - 0.5-1 l/hour. For example, a 10 kW system operates 8 hours a day: 1.5 × 10 × 8 = 120 l/day = 3,600 l/month = 3.6 m³/month. The calculator takes into account the costs of various life support systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for sewerage?
faqItems.a: Water consumption for sewerage is equal to water supply consumption plus additional losses. Typically, sewer flow is assumed to be 95-100% of water supply flow. For example, water supply flow 20 m³/month: sewer flow 20 × 0.95 = 19 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate flow rates for planning sewer systems.

faqItems.q: How to calculate water consumption for a restaurant or cafe?
faqItems.a: To calculate water consumption for a restaurant, use a rate of 150-200 liters per visitor. For example, a restaurant with 100 visitors per day: 175 × 100 = 17,500 l/day = 17.5 m³/day. Per month: 17.5 × 30 = 525 m³/month. At 60% load: 525 × 0.6 = 315 m³/month. The calculator helps calculate consumption for public catering facilities.

faqItems.q: How to calculate the annual water consumption for a private home?
faqItems.a: To calculate the annual water consumption for a private home, multiply the daily consumption by 365 days. For example, a family of 4 with a flow rate of 1,000 l/day: 1,000 × 365 = 365,000 l/year = 365 m³/year. The calculator automatically calculates the annual consumption based on daily consumption and shows the cost for the entire year.

faqItems.q: Is the water consumption calculator free?
faqItems.a: Yes, the water consumption calculator is completely free and does not require registration. You can use it an unlimited number of times to calculate the water consumption of any type of premises and objects. The calculator works online, does not require installation of programs and is available 24/7. All functions, including calculations for various scenarios and data export, are provided free of charge. The service is financed by advertising and is an open tool for all users.

overview.title: About the electricity consumption calculator
overview.content: An online electricity consumption calculator will help you calculate how much electricity your household or building appliances consume per day, month and year. Suitable for cost estimation, tariff selection and energy efficiency analysis.
overview.additionalContent: The electricity consumption calculator uses standard formulas to calculate electricity consumption. The calculation is based on the power of the appliances, operating time, number of appliances, load factor and electricity tariff. Formula: Consumption (kWh) = Power (kW) × Operating time (h) × Quantity × Load factor. Cost = Consumption × Tariff. The calculator supports single-phase (220 V) and three-phase (380 V) electrical networks. You can add several devices and calculate the total consumption with visualization of the results.

calculationExamples.title: Examples of calculating energy consumption
calculationExamples.content: Let's look at practical examples of calculating energy consumption for various use scenarios:

example1.title: Example 1: Electricity consumption in an apartment
example1.description: Calculation of consumption of basic household appliances in an apartment
example1.input:
Refrigerator: 150 W, 24 h/day
TV: 100 W, 5 hours/day
Computer: 200 W, 8 hours/day
Washing machine: 2000 W, 2 hours/day (3 days/week)
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example1.calculation:
Refrigerator: 150 W × 24 hours × 30 days = 108 kWh/month
TV: 100 W × 5 hours × 30 days = 15 kWh/month
Computer: 200 W × 8 hours × 30 days = 48 kWh/month
Washing machine: 2000 W × 2 hours × 12 days = 48 kWh/month

Total consumption: 108 + 15 + 48 + 48 = 219 kWh/month
Cost: 219 × 5.5 = 1,204.5 ₽/month
example1.note: The refrigerator consumes the most electricity due to 24/7 operation

example2.title: Example 2: Electricity consumption in construction
example2.description: Calculation of consumption of construction tools on site
example2.input:
Grinder: 2000 W, 6 hours/day
Drill: 800 W, 4 h/day
Hammer: 1500 W, 3 h/day
Lighting: 500 W, 12 h/day
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh, Working days: 20 days/month
example2.calculation:
Grinder: 2000 W × 6 hours × 20 days = 240 kWh/month
Drill: 800 W × 4 hours × 20 days = 64 kWh/month
Hammer: 1500 W × 3 hours × 20 days = 90 kWh/month
Lighting: 500 W × 12 hours × 20 days = 120 kWh/month

Total consumption: 240 + 64 + 90 + 120 = 514 kWh/month
Cost: 514 × 5.5 = 2,827 ₽/month
example2.note: Construction tools consume a lot of energy due to high power

example3.title: Example 3: Energy consumption in the office
example3.input:
Computers (10 pcs): 150 W, 8 hours/day
Printers (3 pcs): 300 W, 2 hours/day
Air conditioning: 2000 W, 10 h/day
Lighting: 2000 W, 8 hours/day
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh, Working days: 22 days/month
example3.calculation:
Computers: 150 W × 10 pcs × 8 hours × 22 days = 264 kWh/month
Printers: 300 W × 3 pcs × 2 hours × 22 days = 39.6 kWh/month
Air conditioner: 2000 W × 10 hours × 22 days = 440 kWh/month
Lighting: 2000 W × 8 hours × 22 days = 352 kWh/month

Total consumption: 264 + 39.6 + 440 + 352 = 1,095.6 kWh/month
Cost: 1,095.6 × 5.5 = 6,025.8 ₽/month
example3.note: The air conditioner is the main consumer of electricity in the office

example4.title: Example 4: Electricity consumption taking into account the night tariff
example4.input:
Washing machine: 2000 W, 2 h (night rate)
Heater: 1500 W, 8 h (night rate)
Lighting: 500 W, 4 h (daily rate)
Daily tariff: 6 ₽/kWh
Night tariff: 2.5 ₽/kWh
example4.calculation:
Night rate:
Washing machine: 2000 W × 2 h = 4 kWh/day × 2.5 ₽ = 10 ₽/day
Heater: 1500 W × 8 h = 12 kWh/day × 2.5 ₽ = 30 ₽/day

Daily rate:
Lighting: 500 W × 4 h = 2 kWh/day × 6 ₽ = 12 ₽/day

Daily cost: 10 + 30 + 12 = 52 ₽/day
Monthly cost: 52 × 30 = 1,560 ₽/month
example4.note: Using a night tariff allows you to save up to 60% of the cost

example5.title: Example 5: Electricity consumption with load factor
example5.description: Calculation for devices with variable load
example5.input:
Air conditioner: 3000 W (max), load factor 60%
Heater: 2000 W (max), load factor 70%
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh, Work: 12 hours/day
example5.calculation:
Air conditioning:
Effective power: 3000 W × 0.6 = 1,800 W
Consumption: 1,800 W × 12 h = 21.6 kWh/day

Heater:
Effective power: 2000 W × 0.7 = 1,400 W
Consumption: 1,400 W × 12 h = 16.8 kWh/day

Total consumption: 21.6 + 16.8 = 38.4 kWh/day
Monthly consumption: 38.4 × 30 = 1,152 kWh/month
Cost: 1,152 × 5.5 = 6,336 ₽/month
example5.note: The load factor takes into account that the devices are not operating at full power

example6.title: Example 6: Comparison of energy-efficient and conventional appliances
example6.description: Savings from using LED lamps and energy-efficient equipment
example6.input:
Conventional lamps (10 pcs × 60 W): 600 W, 8 hours/day
LED lamps (10 pcs × 9 W): 90 W, 8 hours/day
Old refrigerator: 200 W, 24 h/day
New refrigerator A+++: 100 W, 24 h/day
Tariff: 5.5 ₽/kWh
example6.calculation:
Regular lamps:
Consumption: 600 W × 8 h × 30 = 144 kWh/month
Cost: 144 × 5.5 = 792 ₽/month

LED lamps:
Consumption: 90 W × 8 h × 30 = 21.6 kWh/month
Cost: 21.6 × 5.5 = 118.8 ₽/month

Old refrigerator:
Consumption: 200 W × 24 h × 30 = 144 kWh/month
Cost: 144 × 5.5 = 792 ₽/month

New refrigerator:
Consumption: 100 W × 24 h × 30 = 72 kWh/month
Cost: 72 × 5.5 = 396 ₽/month

Savings: (792 - 118.8) + (792 - 396) = 1,069.2 ₽/month
example6.note: Energy-efficient appliances can reduce consumption by 50-85%

calculation.title: How is electricity consumption calculated?
calculation.content: The calculator uses the formula: Consumption (kWh) = Power (kW) × Running time (h) × Load factor
calculation.single_phase: Single-phase network: P = U × I × cos(φ)
calculation.three_phase: Three-phase network: P = √3 × U × I × cos(φ)
